children.subject: I would also love a functional programming class! 61a really piqued my interest with Scheme and I think there should definitely be a class that goes deeper into these ideas. I've also been very interested in learning OCaml, so that just makes it even better.
<md>+1 for FP!</md>
Please teach the FP class I want to register now.

I would really love a functional programming class. I have been meaning to learn more about it and pick up languages like OCaml and Haskell, so I think this would be a fantastic class to offer.

Web programming is relevant but is partially covered by CS 169 and is also so broad and diverse that I am not sure will provide as much long-term value.

history.content: I think I'll be very interested in taking the web programming class because it's more applied and more useful to students interested in joining the industry.

children.subject: +1 Here. I feel like I've taken a lot (too many?) theory based classes or just have learned about CS theory for a while now. As someone trying to enter industry directly after graduation, the web programming class is something I'll def take.
+1 I definitely agree with this. I think there isn't a course that clearly teaches full-stack development but there are many courses centered around CS theory.

I don't know, I feel like if you want to learn web dev stuff there are more streamlined options that make it much much easier than taking a university style course. 

Though Josh Hug is a pool of infinite wisdom, I feel like you could get a better webdev learning experience through freecodecamp, the oden project, and other places. I used a bunch of these and they help a lot. If you are willing to pay (which is not necessary at all seeing as how there are so many free options) then scrimba is very very cool.

This is where I stand conflicted. What kind of web programming course is it going to be? @Josh Hug If it is going to be anything like what I've heard of CS 169 then I would rather not (I say this as someone who primarily works in web dev and many of even my most complex side projects can be learned already through a few tutorials). 

Functional programming has a syllabus laid out for me that I can easily see is well-organized https://www.cs.princeton.edu/courses/archive/fall20/cos326/info.php and creating a good web course from scratch in OCaml no less seems like a hard job — but if anyone can do it well then Professor Hug would be my goto.

But I also feel like there are multiple DeCals, https://wdd.io/, https://calcloud.org/ as well as a few others that i do not know the links for, (as well as organizations and clubs that accept everyone to work on those sort of projects like the CSUA) that accomplish making full stack web applications. There are many non-competitive-to-get-into (as in they accept everyone) ways to get experience in this area.

Other than CS 61A, you don't really see functional programming and 61A was more of like lambdas are a thing, and then tested mainly recursion and OOP on exams so I feel like a course dedicated to FP would be a great idea. And to echo the above replied in this thread I would personally recommend this to be an applications course: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_programming#Applications that works on a bit of web programming as an application/project/final project for the class. I personally don't think a solely web programming course at Berkeley is the move (it's something that can easily be learned through decals and classes dedicated to it in the past have been disasters that we generally don't speak of as much now) but feel free to followup with your reasoning if you disagree, I'm very interested in hearing others' opinions!
I think I'll be very interested in taking the web programming class because it's more applied and more useful to students interested in joining the industry.

I have the same question, I'm a current freshman who has taken cs61abc/70/eecs16ab/cs161/cs188 and I was wondering if I could enroll or get permission to enroll with junior standing on calcentral? This seems like an awesome class and something I would love to take as I really enjoyed 61a and functional programming in general
oh @14493_f10 says sophomores can enroll (if there is still space by our phase1 i guess) but i still wonder if it is P/NP (for grad school I can't take P/NP classes).

Its open to everyone @14493_f10 

Also, are you speedrunning the CS major or something?? thats a crazy amount of classes for a freshman but props to you

LOL anon poet I have the exact same thought. 
Built Different.

It doesn't have to be p/np. For instance 47a/b are 1 units but you must take those for grade as they're meant to replace 61a/b which must be taken for grade. It would be nice to have the two unit course count towards the cs degree, but I would take it even if it doesn't.

I'd be really interested in taking a functional programming course! What do you think about sophomores taking that class? Would it be too much for me? Also will the class be P/NP then as it is 2 units?
I would be really interested in web programming as I think it would be super useful for industry!
May I ask for some pointers? I have been wanting to get into web dev for a bit now and would love to get together with other students to learn web dev together. thanks so much!

There's an incredible amount of web development resources online as well! I personally used TheOdinProject to learn web dev, and I definitely recommend it if you're interested. It's an open source free online curriculum, and it links a lot of additional resources in each article. Here's a link: https://www.theodinproject.com/
I feel like there's already enough resources at berkeley to learn web dev, maybe functional programming would be a more unique experience that you couldnt get elsewhere

Update: If this happens, it'll be Spring. Depends on whether or not there is someone lined up to teach DS100. If someone else is doing it, I'll do the FP class, otherwise I'll be doing DS100.

history.content:
There is a strong chance I'll be teaching a 2 unit CS194 either next Fall or Spring, with the intended audience as CS/EECS juniors and seniors to learn something they wouldn't otherwise learn.

The two ideas I have in mind are a functional programming class modeled after David Walker's COS326 at Princeton (https://www.cs.princeton.edu/courses/archive/fall20/cos326/info.php) or a web programming class. I'm way more technically comfortable with the former, but I've had to learn some of the latter and it'd be fun to build my web programming skills. 

The web programming class would be a class about hacking together full stack web applications, i.e. html, javascript, setting up a web server VM, jQuery, the d3 visualization library, whatever other stuff is out there these days. 

The functional programming class would do a deep dive into functional programming, of which I am personally quite fond. This would include ideas like monads, algebraic data types, etc. Most likely it would be in OCaml, but I'd maybe be open to using F# (though I've never used it personally).

In some sense, the classes are complete opposites. The web programming is ugly hacking with little to no theory, and the FP class is rigor and beauty.

I'm curious what seems appealing to you.
history.subject: CS194 - Web Programming or Functional Programming (in OCaml)?
